18.35.
A family F of group homomorphisms A → B is separating if for every nontrivial a ∈ A there is f ∈ F such that f(a) ̸= 1, and discriminating if for any finitely many nontrivial elements a1, . . . , an ∈ A there is f ∈ F such that f(ai) ̸= 1 for all i = 1, . . . , n. Let G be a relatively free group of rank 2 in the variety of metabelian groups. Let T be a metabelian group in which the centralizer of every nontrivial element is abelian.
If T admits a separating family of surjective homomorphisms T → G must it also admit a discriminating family of surjective homomorphisms T → G?
A positive answer would give a metabelian analogue of a classical theorem of B. Baumslag.
A. Gaglione, D. Spellman
